misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sc.next() will capture a complete 'name' (e.g., 'Alice Smith') as a single unit because it is being assigned to an index in a String array named 'names'.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In the Java Notional Machine, the Scanner's next() method is whitespace-delimited, not entity-delimited. It reads characters until it encounters any whitespace (space, tab, or newline). The computer does not understand the semantic context that a 'name' may consist of multiple words.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: If a user inputs a first and last name (e.g., 'Alice Smith'), the program will store 'Alice' in names[0] and 'Smith' in names[1]. This will cause the names array to consume tokens intended for the scores array, likely leading to an InputMismatchException when sc.nextInt() is called.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the input stream is partitioned into 'phases' based on the output prompts (e.g., all input provided after the 'Enter names' prompt is strictly for the names loop).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The machine sees the input as a single continuous stream of tokens. The Scanner does not know which System.out.print prompt was most recently displayed. It will keep pulling tokens from the stream as requested by the code, regardless of when the user typed them or what the prompt asked for.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: If a user enters a name and a score on the same line, the names loop will consume the score as a String, misaligning the parallel arrays and causing a logic error or a runtime crash in the subsequent scores loop.
